body: @marco-c Should I take this up? If so, what should these tests include?

This is going to be a bit involved. You're going to have to create a test mercurial repository and generate a few commits in it in order to test all the functions in repository.py.

The first tests, testing the behavior of _transform, should not require a test repository though (you can create some fake commit objects), so you can start with those.

> The first tests, testing the behavior of _transform, should not require a test repository though (you can create some fake commit objects), so you can start with those.

No, actually even for testing _transform you'll need a test repository.
Ok, correct me if I'm wrong, when the tests for repository start, it'll first clone the dummy repo into tests/data, and then test the repository function, right?
The test itself will create the repository, it won't clone it.

Could you explain what you mean by the test creating the repository? I was thinking about hosting a dummy repo on bitbucket, and cloning it at the time of the test (I'm guessing there's an extension to clone hg repo from python?).

Having the test repository outside of this repository will make it much harder to add new tests and modify the existing ones. Also, it will make it hard to perform bisection.

Instead, we can just create the repository locally as part of the test setup.

Sure, I'll add the repo to test/data. Also, off topic: how is https://github.com/mozilla/bugbug/blob/master/bugbug/repository.py#L122 supposed to be used? (I keep getting empty lists). The date parameter is the date from which all commits should be collected, I reckon? 

`hg.log(revrange='pushdate("{}")'.format(datetime.datetime(2019, 1, 1, 0,0,0).strftime('%Y-%m-%d')), limit=1)`gives me an empty list ,although there are commits after the date.

> Sure, I'll add the repo to test/data

It's better if we create the repo programmatically with Python, using hglib. Having a whole repo inside the repo just for testing purposes would have a few problems too (not easily modifiable).

> Also, off topic: how is https://github.com/mozilla/bugbug/blob/master/bugbug/repository.py#L122 supposed to be used?

You'll need to enable these three mercurial extensions:
```
pushlog = /PATH/version-control-tools/hgext/pushlog
hgmo = /PATH/version-control-tools/hgext/hgmo
mozext = /PATH/version-control-tools/hgext/mozext
```

If you run `./mach boostrap` or `./mach vcs-setup` in your mozilla-central clone, /PATH will be YOUR_HOME_DIRECTORY/.mozbuild/

> It's better if we create the repo programmatically with Python, using hglib. Having a whole repo inside the repo just for testing purposes would have a few problems too (not easily modifiable).

Here's a brief example from another project, you can take inspiration from it https://github.com/mozilla/release-services/blob/549691a0365854fe0c9e03c01728b7f66d7cbe9b/src/staticanalysis/bot/tests/conftest.py#L53.

@marco-c I've updated my hg to 4.9, and added all those extensions, however I still get an empty list:
```
>>> import bugbug
>>> import datetime
>>> import hglib
>>> hg = hglib.open("mozilla-central")
>>> hg.log(revrange='pushdate("{}")'.format(datetime.datetime(2019,1,1,1,1,1).strftime('%Y-%m-%d')), limit=1)
[]
```
Using only `hg.log()` gives the correct results. Any idea why this is happening?

> > It's better if we create the repo programmatically with Python, using hglib. Having a whole repo inside the repo just for testing purposes would have a few problems too (not easily modifiable).
> 
> Here's a brief example from another project, you can take inspiration from it https://github.com/mozilla/release-services/blob/549691a0365854fe0c9e03c01728b7f66d7cbe9b/src/staticanalysis/bot/tests/conftest.py#L53.

Also, can you please test if the `client.commit()` function works for you? (I keep getting a `hglib.error.CommandError: (1, b'committing files:
test.cpp
test.txt
committing manifest
committing changelog
updating the branch cache
nothing changed', b'')`). I'm on Python3.7 , hg 4.8.2.

issue.title: Improve documentation about how to use repository.py

repository.name: bugbug
repository.description: Platform for Machine Learning projects on Software Engineering

issue.body:
I am facing this particular issue when running repository.py 
@marco-c  @ayush1999 

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "bugbug/bugbug/repository.py", line 203, in <module>
    download_commits(args.repository_dir, two_years_and_six_months_ago)
  File "bugbug/bugbug/repository.py", line 129, in download_commits
    first_rev = get_rev(hg, date_from)
  File "bugbug/bugbug/repository.py", line 123, in get_rev
    return hg.log(revrange='pushdate("{}")'.format(date.strftime('%Y-%m-%d')), limit=1)[0].node.decode('utf-8')
  File "C:\ProgramData\Anaconda3\lib\site-packages\hglib\client.py", line 1102, in log
    out = self.rawcommand(args)
  File "C:\ProgramData\Anaconda3\lib\site-packages\hglib\client.py", line 263, in rawcommand
    raise error.CommandError(args, ret, out, err)
hglib.error.CommandError: (255, b'', b'hg: parse error: unknown identifier: pushdate\n(did you mean date?)')

```

body:
> Using only hg.log() gives the correct results. Any idea why this is happening?

Not sure, maybe your pushlog database is empty. It will probably be rebuilt if you go in the repo directory and run `hg pull central` and `hg up central`.

> Also, can you please test if the client.commit() functions works for you?

Yes, the test I sent you works for me.

> > Using only hg.log() gives the correct results. Any idea why this is happening?
> 
> Not sure, maybe your pushlog database is empty. It will probably be rebuilt if you go in the repo directory and run `hg pull central` and `hg up central`.

Great, this got it running for me. Thanks :+1: 


> > Also, can you please test if the client.commit() functions works for you?
> 
> Yes, the test I sent you works for me.

It still doesn't work for me. It's probably because of version issues. Can you tell me what python and hg you're on?

Python 3.7.2+ and Mercurial 4.8.

Can you show me exactly what code you're running?

Sure:
```
test_path = 'tests/fixtures/test_repository'
hglib.init(test_path)

client = hglib.open(test_path)

path = os.path.join(test_path, 'test.txt')
with open(path, 'w') as f:
    f.write('Hello World\n')
client.add(path.encode('utf-8'))

path = os.path.join(test_path, 'test.cpp')
with open(path, 'w') as f:
    f.write('Hello World\n')
client.add(path.encode('utf-8'))

client.commit(b'Hello World', user=b'Tester')
```
Error: 
```
hglib.error.CommandError: (1, b'committing files:\ntest.cpp\ntest.txt\ncommitting manifest\ncommitting changelog\nupdating the branch cache\nnothing changed', b'')

../bbug/lib/python3.7/site-packages/hglib/client.py:263: CommandError
```

Can you please tell me where I might be going wrong?

Your script works for me. Have you tried running it as a script in isolation from tests?

When using it as a fixture, try using a temporary directory instead as test_path (using https://docs.pytest.org/en/latest/tmpdir.html).

@marco-c Yes, I tried that, the `commit()` function still results in an error. I'm on Python 3.7.1, hg 4.8.2. Is it possible this is because of some version errors? (If so, I'll try using the exact python version you're on.)
It's very strange, I wouldn't expect this to be due to some version problem.
I remember this to be working on my earlier system. I changed my system couple of days back, and it's been failing ever since.
